Hey Everyone,

Congratulation on a successful end to this semester!

With reacclimation and adjusting to in-person learning, that is no small task, especially with consideration the percent of this class that is just finishing their sophomore year. This is a pretty deep place to jump into everything. Please trust that see that and have definitely taken that into consideration. Personally, I think I speak for all members of Team 280 when I say that we are proud of the level of perseverance, determination and growth that each of you has exhibited in the face of this distinct challenge. I really hope that this will give you a running start as you enter into your upperclassmanship next semester.

Final Grades have been posted to Sakai.

Please do not hesitate to reach out to us for any reason. We look forward to seeing the great things that you do, helping you any way we can, and sharing in your celebrations. Until then, I sincerely hope that this summer is fruitful and productive when it needs to be, and otherwise, I hope that it offers you the respite that you rightly deserve.

Wishing you the best in all of your future endeavors! I look forward to hearing from you!

Sincerely,

Chance Fleeting

author: Chance Fleeting
title: More Details on the Final
body:
In follow-up to Dr. C's announcement, I wanted to provide a detailed outline for tomorrow's final. PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING FULLY AND CAREFULLY.

Start time: 9 am 04/27/2022 

 

Duration: 3 hours with time considerations for printing/scanning and accommodations where applicable.

 

Length: 8 question. 2 Extra credit questions

 

Material: Cumulative throughout the semester. Mainly conceptual. Methodological knowledge may include Laplace transform, PFE, Fourier Series/Transform, and convolution as well as other operations applicable to this course.

HERE IS THE EXACT OUTLINE OF THE EXAM:

  1. Concept Drill (20%)
  2. Sinusoid Analysis (12%)
  3. Laplace 1 (15%)
  4. Communication-Relay (10%)
  5. Laplace 2 (12 %)
  6. Laplace 3 (11%)
  7. Convolution (Analytical) (10%)
  8. Convolution (Graphical) (10%)
  9. EC (+4%)
  10. Penalties -- Sign the DCS and Provide your name where instructed

 

Grading: No curve will be applied, but as Dr. C mentioned in class, she implements a multi-schema grading system. To highlight strengths of each student, Dr.C implements 5 additional perturbed versions of the grading schema provided on the syllabus and you are provided with your maximum possible score. Depending on how well you do on the exam relative to your other assignments, this test will be worth 23, 25, or 33 percent of your overall grade. All Schemas are provided below:

HW Lab Test1 Test2 Final
Default 0.15 0.2 0.2 0.2 0.25
HW-Boost 0.23 0.18 0.18 0.18 0.23
Lab-Boost 0.13 0.28 0.18 0.18 0.23
Start-Strong 0.13 0.18 0.28 0.18 0.23
Peak 0.13 0.18 0.18 0.28 0.23
Finish-Strong 0.13 0.18 0.18 0.18 0.33

 

 

Mode: Virtual

Due to time restrictions, we are setting up the test in a fully virtualize format that will help expediate the grading process. In the morning, 2 assignments will become available on Gradescope at 9am sharp. The "Final" assignment and "Final_companion" assignment. 

  • > The primary "Final" assignment provides a copy of all the same questions presented in the paper exam, but with text boxes that allow you to input your answers for each question. This is the primary method of grading, allowing us to "automatically" filter out most correct answers.
  • > The  "Final_companion" includes a PDF of the test and the whole equation sheet, as well as the traditional submission method (print, complete, scan, label, submit). This is secondary mode of grading that will allow us to provide partial credit based on work and adjustability with unfamiliar formats and equivalent solutions.
  • > Technical logistics such as typing time, submission, and printing have been accounted when setting up the test-timing. 
  • > For Questions that require no work or "long-response" typed responses are preferred since they are easier to grade. 

Proctoring will be via Zoom.

  • > All students must keep their camera/mic on for the duration of the exam. Please find a comfortable and quiet place to test. 
  • > Any questions you have for Dr.C (material) and I (technical) will be through the private chat. We will be available for the full duration of the exam (including accommodations where that applies).
  • > The test Zoom link is the following:  https://duke.zoom.us/j/99875076765
    • PLEASE BE PROMPT. Attendance of the Zoom meeting will be cross-referenced at 9 am. You must be on the Zoom call to take the test.

 

Extra Office Hours:

4pm - 6pm : Rishi/Clay in Teer 116

6pm - 8pm : Chance on Zoom: https://duke.zoom.us/j/95369582123

 

RELAX. GOOD LUCK. DRINK WATER

author: Chance Fleeting
title: More Notes on the Laplace transform of Periodic Functions
body:
The Bilateral Laplace transform of a truly periodic function x(t) does not converge (has no ROC)... BUT! The math still works. The solution you will get will have poles on the imaginary axis. The right of the imaginary axis we know we have an ROC defining a strictly causal/rightfacing signal and to the left, a strictly anticausal/leftfacing signal. Given our definition of periodicity, our signal should be ever-present, not fitting in either of these groups, so what gives?

Well, the Laplace transform of a truly periodic signal does not really exist...

Instead, the solution spits out a X(s) that corresponds to two functions-- one ROC that would corresponding to the right facing component, and another that would correspond with the left facing component. Both of which may seem like their missing information... at first. 

In reality, the information in a periodic signal is REDUNDANT. As we saw with the FS, we could learn everything we want about a periodic signal by looking at a single period. That would mean to reason that we would definitely know everything given the full right facing component. 

This moves into a moderately controversial area of mathematics that gets uglier the deeper we go with predicate convergence, ordinary points and other mathy weirdness... but we are engineers. Same information is present, so we don't see anything broken. But this is another thing, like with the delta function, that will spark debate between us, the physicist and mathematicians. 

It's a cool thought experiment if you want to dive into it, but for the point of this HW, feel free to assume convergence and test those assumptions. You'll find cool things.

 

Best,

Chance

author: Sanika Gupte
title: ECE 280 Lab Blast - Lab 9: AM Radio Lab
body:
Hi everyone,

This week is the last week of labs! It's definitely sad for me, but regardless if you are happy or sad, I can promise you that this lab is super fun and you will not be disappointed.

It's AM Radio lab this week!!! In this lab, you'll have the opportunity to create your very own AM radio station with the function generator and pick up the signal using a physical hand-crank radio. Then we'll talk about how to recover the modulated signal using an envelope detection circuit  (which can also be used for Ultrasound circuits for those of you who are interested in medical devices) and do some frequency domain analysis of what's happening.

The lab manual is posted on Sakai and the PowerPoint presentation is located here. Reading the documentation before coming into lab will definitely make this lab go faster so please at least skim it over before your section.

IMPORTANT INFORMATION!!!

That being said, this lab is a fully in-person lab and you will not be able to complete it if you leave immediately after the presentation or show up late, as it will likely take the whole time. If you are late this week, we will have to apply the attendance penalty (50% deduction) to your lab grade. Please do not risk coming in late this week.

Let me know if you have any questions. I'm really looking forward to this week!

Sanika :)

author: Sanika Gupte
title: ECE 280 Lab Blast - Lab 8: Voice Scrambler Descrambler
body:
Hi everyone,


We're so close to the end of this semester! We only have TWO more labs left before we are done. Time is flying by wayyy too quickly. 

Just a few quick reminders...

1. Lab 7: Image Processing Part 2 is due before your lab section this week.

2. All lab reports must be completed to pass the course, so please get any outstanding lab reports to us as soon as you can.

 

This week we will be doing Lab 8: Voice Scrambler and Descrambler.

The voice scrambler system from this lab can be used to transform a signal into and out of a virtually unintelligible state by flipping the low and high frequencies, which we will do by multiplying our signal by a special sinusoid. True scrambling is a lot more complicated than what we’ll be implementing in lab. It helped to encrypt telecommunications during WWII and generally employed a more sophisticated stochastic or key carrier that would require the same carrier to decipher the audio data presented, allowing the message, if intercepted in-between, to remain unintelligible and secure. This type of manipulation can also be applied to amplitude modulation for AM radio communication, which we will be doing in our final lab for this class (Lab 9). The PowerPoint summary can be located here.

 

Good luck with lab this week! Let us know if you have any questions, comments, or concerns.

 

Sanika

author: Sanika Gupte
title: ECE 280 Lab Blast - Lab 7: Image Processing Part 2
body:
Hey everyone,

 

We have the second image processing lab this week! Please make sure to turn in the Sampling and Aliasing Lab on Gradescope before the start of your lab period. If you have any questions, please post them on Ed Discussions!

 

In the first image processing lab, we applied different kernels on images in the spatial domain using MATLAB’s conv2 function. Recall from lecture that the convolution operation in time is equivalent to multiplication in frequency. Like 1-D time signals, this holds true for images, except we’re looking at space instead of time, and we will have frequency content in two dimensions (u and v). We will now be designing filters in the spatial frequency domain using MATLAB’s fft2 function. Specifically, we’ll look at binary low pass, high pass, and band pass filters, which are easier to create and faster to compute in the frequency domain rather than its spatial domain convolution counterpart.

 

Please READ THE LAB DOCUMENTATION before attending your lab section. There are 10 exercises in total and many examples interspersed, but by the end of the lab, you'll have a thorough idea of how to represent systems in the frequency domain. Having a general understanding of the lab beforehand will definitely help things run more smoothly. I would also highly recommend reviewing the Pratt Pundit page, which has supplemental information and copy and pastable code templates for the lab, as well as our summary PowerPoint here.

 

Feel free to reach out with any questions, comments, or concerns!

 

Sanika

author: Leslie Collins
title: Follow on to Chance’s Survey Results announcement
body:
Hey all - thanks for filling out the survey!  Chance and I sat down together and went through the responses today.  Thanks “infinity” to Chance for writing up the previous announcement!

I want to echo what Chance says - we are here to help you, and 100% believe you can all be successful in 280!  As Chance noted, I will be creating a couple of new online lectures both to provide some examples, but to also provide some “big picture” thoughts on how the whole course ties together now that we are 2/3 of the way through… more or less.  I plan to get those lectures posted no later than Sunday.

As Chance mentions in his post, and as I have announced in class every week - I’m totally happy to meet with people one on one or in small groups to re-go over topics if there is some confusion.  There are indeed multiple ways to solve these different problems.  For example, but not exclusively, for convolution we can do analytical or graphical.  For proof of a FT pair you can prove starting in the time domain and going to the frequency domain, or starting in the frequency domain and going to the time domain.  Learning when to use each approach is part of the intuition we’re trying to help you build.  I’m happy to sit down with people, even on weekends, and work through any concepts that are troubling you, or to go back over class notes to explain things again, or more deeply, or whatever you need.

Let me reiterate - every semester there is confusion in moving from the time domain to the frequency domain.  Generally, it isn’t easy so it is completely natural to have some confusion and even frustration!  It is all part of the learning process.  But that’s why we picked engineering - because it is challenging, interesting, and you get to solve really interesting and meaningful problems.  But nope, it’s not easy and we rarely have cookie cutter solutions.  But Team ECE 280 is here and we are all willing to help!!!

author: Chance Fleeting
title: Survey Results are in!
body:
Hey Everyone,

I just reviewed the survey results, and there were a couple common themes. I've put a response to each below in a pseudo outline form. It's a lot. I know. My hope is that splitting it into topics should help make it a little easier to read.

There were also some concerns that were specific to different individuals. In light of that, I would very much like to open a dialog. I will be sending out some form of sign up to help schedule 1-on-1 meetings with each of you before Test 2 so that we can root out any outstanding issues at an individual level and help prepare you to face the rest of this course and the courses that follow. You are all smart. You wouldn't be here if you weren't. While this last year has been distinct and difficult, I am confident that you all are in fact "cut-out" for this and that you can succeed.

This material can be a tough transition. Please know you are not alone in feeling that, but for now, I hope that this can help.

Best,
Chance

 

1. TA office hours time: More evening TA office hours were requested.

I'll work with the early morning TAs to see if we can get more evening office hours (including weekend office hours). I’ll update Sakai to correspond with any changes in the office hours. Please keep an eye on the overview page for ECE280 for office hour updates. In the meantime, Dr. Collins and I do provide additions office hours by appointment and by request. Just send us an email and we can put something together.

2. Fully Worked Complex Examples.

  • While fully worked example of practical “real-life” problems that are generally more involved than what you see on the HW and working through “non-toy” examples akin to your HW is not something that is allotted for within the instructional time in class based on curriculum requirement, both are very useful in building an intuition for this type of material, but more so that intuition is built by doing rather than observation. That being said, I’ve talked to Dr. C and she has offered to record extra lectures running through some more “realistic” convolution and/or frequency domain information. I may also jump on this train to approach the example from a different direction (e.g. Audio processing or circuits) if time allows.

    Relating to difficulty as perceived, concerns about set-up and how to get started, there is something we have to note here that may be new compared to previous classes you have had. The work in this class (and many higher level engineering courses) will often be non-state-dependent, meaning that with much of this material, there is more than one way to reach the answer, and often, there are many equally valid ways to express the same answer. For this reason, there isn’t a single one-size-fits-all set up for all questions. Some questions are more well suited to different approaches and preference of those approaches vary drastically from individual to individual. Some people prefer exploiting properties and known identities ad nauseam, some like to just run headfirst into integration, and others leverage graphical and “trick” methods, and even within that divide, the actual path of operation may vary drastically. Different problems and different people prefer different things, and generally the starting point provided in the HW problems is set-up all up until that divergence occurs. The intention is that you try stuff, get stuck, and possibly try to approach the problem from a different angle (e.g. Analysis equation looks hard for this problem, let me try working backwards with the synthesis equation or look at my equation sheet). Math errors, if not conceptual, should only be minor a deduction since we are more interested in whether you can conceptually try and approach these problems, which is generally held in your work and methodology. Our goal is for you to find how you specifically best approach each of these tasks. That is the main component of this course that will translate into the courses that follow more so than any given formula or notation.

    As a benchmark, we design the HW to take between 1.5-3 hours a week (excluding HW4 which was intended to be 10-20 minutes per part for spring break) and we typically try and scale the difficulty from simple/easier to more complex problems as you proceed through the assignment (with a few pace-breaking exceptions) requiring only material that has been covered prior to the assignment release date. More time can be expected if the topic is just “not clicking”, but if the work seems unbearable or excessive or you’re getting stuck, that may be an indication that you are approaching a given problem in a way that is not the best for you. You’re not dumb. You didn’t mess up. You just went the different direction at the divergence and are now on a different path. It’s going to the same location but might have a few hurdles that you don’t like. At that point you can either try and rough it out and explore the “hard way” or step back and take a second look for another way to approach it. Either way, my recommendation to get started is to jump in and try stuff. As your intuition grows, you’ll be more directional in how you approach different problems, but for now, don’t be afraid of jumping to trial-and-error of methodology when figuring out what works best for you.

    Along those lines, don’t fall into the trap of analysis paralysis and default to however a given member of Team280 (including myself) approaches a problem. Our goal at office hours is by working with you to find what method works best specifically for you, not to give you answers or work the problems out for you. We will help show you new ways to do it, and we are eager to happy to help you, but we won’t be sitting next to you on test day.

3. Conceptual difficulty with Fourier Series/Transform and Convolution.

  • There is some addition conceptualized explanation included at the end of the Extra Credit assignment if you'd like to check that out, but it does get pretty far into the weeds with high-level mathematics, generalizations, and information theory that are beyond the expectation of this class. I'm seeing if I can put together a couple more human/tangible explanations of what each of the things do and why they are what they are. Since we work with general "signals" in this class, a lot of times these explanation can vary based on application. At their heart, both are Fourier Series/Transform and Convolution are mathematical tools that make engineering problems (generic systems) easier to solve or analyze, but I can try and throw some physical or application-specific manifestation at you all to see if it makes easier to "see it" in a new light and build an intuition. I'll try and set up a video lecture/office hours to go over other ways to look at/experience the Frequency Domain and Convolution. In the meantime, here is a little sample:
     
    • :: Convolution is a mathematical operation akin to multiplication, sharing many properties with multiplication. It originally arose in physics/mathematics as a common way to express the general solution to different linear differential equations (specifically D'Alembert's solution to the wave equation and analysis of the Taylor Series), but since then, its uses have expanded across mathematics to stats to computer science to engineering (not in that order). In the scope of Signal Processing, it often just "pops up" (such as when when we find the Fourier transform of amplitude modulated signals or process additive noise), but it is also leveraged as a tool to perform a single very useful function -- modelling or using an LTI system, generally for the purpose of filtering. The manifestation of these again varies based on what type of signal we are processing (e.g. audio v.s. visual v.s. biomedical) and what type of system we are using (e.g. mechanical v.s. electrical v.s. biological), but the math stays the same. A few really common examples that you may have experienced are in image processing (applying blur or sharpening/edge-detection filters) or in audio either with explicit filtering/EQ/Equalizing/Mixing or with reverb/delay.

      Without applying too much ECE-specific processing, you can hear "convolution happening" with acoustic reverb. Next time you're in a large room (like one of our auditoriums, Cameron Stadium or Duke Chapel), do one hard clap. That is an impulse. You will notice that the sound lingers -- that is the impulse response. Most acoustic responses are linear, so in theory (and application) you could record and convolve that impulse response with ANY audio signal to make it sound like it was produced in that room. Without popping out your computer, it may just be easier to just listen to all other sounds in the room. As security is fussing at you for just randomly clapping, notice how his voice also lingers and decays in the same way as it did with your clap. Conceptually (through the shifting property of impulses) you can imagine the security guard's voice as a bunch of claps, scaled at different volumes/amplitudes and pushed together into a continuous stream of audio. Since the reverb of this room is an LTI system, each of these infinitesimally close claps that come out of the guards mouth experiences the same impulse response and each is superimposed onto the previous resulting in that distinct sustain-decay that you are hearing with all audio in the room. This same superposition applies with the by-standard's voice that chime in, talking over the security guard to come to your defense as a sophomore signal processor. Both voices blend together and decay in the same manner, adding onto each other. As you have just likely spaced-out for indistinct amount of time, the guard's anger would have likely mellowed to concern as he escorts you out of the building, but at least you now have a reference for convolution, so that's good.
       
    • :: As tools, the Fourier Transforms and Fourier Series can be seen as either characterizing and mapping the distribution of a given signal's energy and phase over the the frequency domain or characterizing the frequency response of a system. The latter example can be seen with an LTI system if we take x(t) = exp( j \omega t) as our input. Our output would be some shifted and scaled complex exponential at the same frequency y(t) = A(\omega) exp(j (\omega t + \theta(\omega))) =  A(\omega)exp(j\theta(\omega))exp(j\omega t) where the shift and gain are likely to vary with frequency. We can then combine these terms into the amplitude gain A(\omega) and phase-shift exp(j\theta(\omega)) into a complex number characterizing our "frequency response" H(j\omega) = A(\omega)exp(j\theta(\omega)). The Fourier Transform is this same process, but simplified by ignoring the part of the output signal that matches the input in favor of just looking at how the complex gain is applied, which allows us conceptually to understand how systems alter the frequency components of signals both for design purposes (e.g. making/visualizing a Low-Pass/High-Pass Filter or speech processing system) or analyzing properties of the system (e.g. Identifying the timbre of an instrument or resonant frequency of a bridge). Counter intuitively, an true impulse, modelled as a dirac delta, represents a scaled sum of all complex exponentials, coupling with a constant in the frequency domain, meaning that the Fourier Transform of the impulse response of a given LTI system characterizes the whole Frequency Response of a system. General terms you may hear to describe a system's frequency response are Low-Pass, High-Pass, Band-Pass, Band-Stop/Notch, and All-Pass filtering, which each describe the magnitude response into which frequency signals are Passed (non-attenuated) or Stopped (attenuated). For instance, a Low-Pass Filter passes Low Frequency signals while stopping High Frequency signals.

      Through similar logic, this method can be applied in reverse -- imagine a complex system  h(t) = exp( j \omega t) where you have a knob that sets \omega to any frequency you choose. By sweeping \omega across the range of all frequencies you choose, you are effectively probing your input signal x(t) to check which frequencies resonate, amplify, attenuate, or delay your given signal. This is a "sweep test" and is similar to the way that many old oscilliscopes would *estimate* the spectra of your signals. This gain/delay quantification as a function of frequency is again synonymous with the Fourier Transform (or spectra) of that given signal. You can think of this more generally as the "fingerprint" or recipe of that given signal that breaks it down into components showing "how much" of each elementary signal (sinusoids/complex exponentials) is required to make our original signal. With other transforms, such as the Laplace or Mellin Transform, your signal is broken down in reference to other elementary signals, but the recipe idea remains the same. By breaking down our signals in this way, we are not only able to analyze them more directly (e.g. visualizing what part of our signal is lost when applying a low pass filter) but also  we can simplify different complex mathematics concepts/operations (e.g. use multiplication instead of convolution).

      As a side note, we generally talk about this as a time-frequency relationship, but this transform doesn't actually care about units in a general sense. Any parameter that you provide and return your input expressed in inverse units. If you supply a shape that is expressed in meters, it will return an interpretation of that shape in terms of inverse meters (e.g. wavenumbers in k-space). Effectively, you are taking the your initial parameter's number line and inverting it. Things that were "skinny" become "fat" and vice versa. This may be a little abstract, but personally, this understanding has helped me with more sanity checks than I'd like to admit.

      In a similar vain, the Fourier Series is really just a special case of the Fourier transform that we use with periodic signals. Since we know that periodic signals can only be comprised of signals that share a period with it, our frequency search is restricted to only constants (DC-value) and exponentials/sinusoids that are harmonic with out analyte signal, forming as a set of spikes/impulses in the frequency domain. Further, rather than expressing this continuously as an impulse train, we can express this discretely as purely the gain factors applied to each constituent harmonic, and for ease of use, change our units to be relative to our fundamental frequency (k=1 harmonic). Voila, Fourier Series. 

      As a little bonus, we like the Fourier Transform since the parameter of Frequency has some tangible physical meaning -- for instance, if you were to look at the spectrum for any major chord, you'd notice the largest spikes spaced at your base note frequency (e.g. A4 = 440Hz or 880pi), major third (e.g. C4# = ~554Hz or (800pi)*2^(4/12)), and major fifth (e.g. E4 = ~659Hz or (800pi)*2^(7/12) ). Depending on the timbre and specific harmonic frequency response of that instrument, you may have other harmonics pop up, but those 3 notes will end up being the most prolific if a major chord is struck. Also note that as volume/loudness is a log measure of amplitude, we perceive frequency in logarithmic units as "pitch" where each octave has frequency double that of its predecessor, and in western music theory that follows equal temperament, 12 chromatic notes are divided into that region. This has to do partially with a phenomenon called "Weber's law" and JND and partially with resonance and the mechanics of how our cochlea functions.

author: Sanika Gupte
title: ECE 280 Weekly Lab Blast - Lab 6: Sampling and Aliasing
body:
Hello signal processors,

 

In lab this week, we’ll be diving into a new topic, sampling and aliasing, which is an essential concept for discrete signal processing.

 

  1. First, Lab 5: Image Processing Part 1 is due this week before your lab section. The Gradescope assignment should be available for submissions now.
  2. Now for this week’s lab on Sampling and Aliasing (READ THE LAB DOCUMENTATION)
  • What is sampling?
    • Sampling is the act of converting data from analog continuous-time into digital discrete-time. Even though most real-world signals are analog, pretty much all of the signal processing that is done on your computers is handled discretely. On our digital devices, we can only collect data at discrete time intervals, denoted by the sampling period (Ts) and the sampling frequency, or sampling rate rate, (fs = 1/Ts).
  • What is aliasing?
    • While sampling is a great tool for discrete signal processing, as you may guess, it can come at a cost since we cannot represent our entire signal through an infinite amount of points. Drawing from your signal processing knowledge, here’s a reason why:
    • Sampling is modeled by multiplying your time-domain signal x(t) with an impulse train s(t) spaced by Ts, your sampling period. Thinking back to the duality and Fourier Transform properties, we know that multiplication in time is equivalent to convolving in the frequency domain. Because of impulse train properties and cool math, we find that the frequency spectrum of our sampled signal X(jω) will look like shifted scaled identical copies (“replicas”) of our original signal spectra centered at integer multiples of our sampling frequency.

 

You can see that our results may change depending on the frequency you sample at. If the sampling frequency is too low, you’ll get overlap between your replicas, which is the root cause of aliasing and results in a distorted reconstruction of your original signal. How can we avoid this?

  • Band-limiting your signal
    • A common technique to avoid overlap in the frequency domain is to band-limit your input signal with an analog low pass filter (aLPF), which we creatively call an Anti-Aliasing Filter. But, arbitrarily cutting off high-frequency signals will definitely put us at risk for losing information; besides, how would we know what cut-off frequency to use? 
  • The Nyquist Criterion
    • fmax ≤ fs/2
      • Our cutoff frequency should be picked so that it is less that half of the sampling frequency. 
    • Also, fs ≥ 2fmax
      • This states that the sampling rate should be at least twice the bandwidth of the signal's waveform being sampled. Sampling faster than this rate assures that the waveform can be reconstructed accurately!
  • So there we go, fs/2 is our cut off, or we just have to pick a higher sampling rate (more expensive) to work with. We’ll be working with these concepts in our lab this week, so please READ THE LAB DOCUMENTATION and check out this powerpoint for a summary of the lab.

 

In the meantime, feel free to reach out to me and the TAs if you have any questions, comments, or concerns.

 

Best,

Sanika

author: Chance Fleeting
title: HW5 Extension and Integral Content
body:
Hey Everyone,
 

I hope Spring Break treated you well!
 

It has come to our attention that some students may not be comfortable with the mathematical content of the material covered in this course. Since in engineering, and particularly in signal processing, our concepts are founded in the basis of math, this content is unavoidable. As you practice you may find simplification methods, such as leveraging properties, symmetries, and common identities, help mitigate the rigor of this mathematical content and find your preferred method of operation in solving signals processing problems. Homework provides this practice.

Calculus II is a prerequisite for this course via ECE110, so there is an expectation that the students have a foundational knowledge and understanding of integration and summation. The ability to use single dimensional change of variable/basis (u-sub) and integration-by-parts is necessary in this course if you are computing solutions manually, and both of these methods are still listed in the standard Calculus II curriculum.

Within the scope of this class, much of our material, including but not limited to convolution, P/E, Fourier Series, Fourier Transform, Correlation, Laplace Transforms, and so on, inherently requires integration at least at the beginning steps. Once students develop a mathematical "intuition" thorough practicing the math, that allows them to leverage the other material that they have at their disposal. For instance, once you are familiar with your Fourier Transform, you can bypass convolution by moving into the frequency domain, multiply the frequency responses and return to the time domain. However, as you can see this requires experience with the Fourier Transform.
 

With that, it is important to recognize that based on the nature of the upcoming material involving frequency domain analysis, sampling theory, communication application, and the Laplace Transform, the integration content is likely to increase. It is unavoidable without shorting your education and causing you to be ill-prepared moving forward.

To that end, **Dr. Collins has authorized me to extend the due date for HW5 by 1 week (now due 10:05 am 03/29/2022) and I am putting together a math primer extra-credit assignment** that should help you become more prepared and comfortable with the Calculus II material that will be required with the topics that are just on the horizon, specifically referencing integration-by-parts, change of basis/variable, FTC, geometric sums, and arithmetic sums, as well as "tricks" such as horizontal/vertical decomposition, exploitation of symmetry, and signal manipulation, that may be helpful. I am writing it now, and I hope to have it reviewed and available asap. Note that this will not be covering application-specific properties or identities that are readily available in your equation sheet packet. If you would like to discuss and practice those, please feel free to visit any of our office hours. We would be more than happy to help you with those.

This assignment will be sharing the 03/29/2022 due date and time with HW5, but is currently ineligible for extension or late submission since it is Extra-Credit and I will be aiming to release the solution immediately after the deadline. Partial credit is permitted, however, so do your best. So long as you don't do it in-place of HW5, It can only help you. The current plan is to include it with equal weight as all other HW assignments, but not include it in the denominator for grade calculation.

Finally, I want you all to know that. We are here, we are listening. We would not be here doing this if your success was not paramount to us, and that includes your well-being. For many of us, it wasn't that long ago that we were in your shoes, and while conditions have changed in that time, we still try to understand. We are aware that this is a relatively stressful and confusing time in your lives. That is definitely within our consideration. Please do not hesitate to reach out to us. We are here to help, and our door is always open. I am just an email away, and I am confident that it is the same with the other members of Team 280.

Please always feel free to reach out to me with any questions, comments, or concerns. I am here.

Kind Regards,
Chance

 

P.S. Please try to start HW5 ASAP if you not already done so. It is very similar to HW4, but may be more involved mathematically just based on the nature of the Fourier Transform. We want you to have time to ask questions and seek help if needed. Much of the material past this point will build on the Fourier Transform. AGAIN, I am here if you need any assistance.

author: Sanika Gupte
title: ECE 280 Weekly Lab Blast - Lab 5: Image Processing
body:
Hey eveyone,

 

I hope you all are having a restful and relaxing spring break.

 

We’re back in lab this week for something new and fun: image processing! Here’s a quick summary of what’s to come:

 

1. First, your Lab 4 report is due this week. You know the deal - make sure to submit your pdf on Gradescope before your lab section this week.

 

2. The Music Competition Results are IN!

The winner of the music competition is Luke Redmore with Another Day in the Sun. Luke, we should have a prize for you soon. I want to say congratulations to everyone, even if your song didn’t get chosen, for all the work you put into your masterpieces. I hope you enjoyed that little project because I think you did a fantastic job. You’re all winners in my book :)

 

3. Background on Image Processing

We’ve been working with 1-D signals and systems to process stock data, digital audio, etc. but these concepts can be extended into 2-D signals, like images. Instead of creating your signal with an array, your image signal will be a matrix, where each element represents a pixel and contains information about its corresponding intensity. And now, rather than doing 1-D convolution to transform your signal, you will now perform 2-D convolution to process the signal, which still consists of flipping and sliding (but now doing all of this in two directions). Digital image processing is typically done after the formation of your image to reduce noise and other distortions. It is also the basis for things you may see and use often, like Instagram filters, contrast enhancement, HDR, image segmentation, and so much more!

 

4. Image Processing Lab

For your lab, you will explore how to display grayscale and color images using MATLAB and play around with common filters (box, Gaussian, and Prewitt just to name a few). Prior to coming into lab, please DOWNLOAD THE IMAGE PROCESSING TOOLBOX in MATLAB. You can find this in the “HOME” tab, clicking “Add-Ons,” and searching for "image processing".

 

5. How to get out of lab faster...

This is a lengthier lab. There are eight exercises in total with many examples interspersed, so having a general understanding of the lab beforehand will help things run more smoothly. The lab is split into EXERCISES, which you need to submit, and EXAMPLES, which you do not need to submit but walking through them will greatly help you to complete the exercises. I would HIGHLY recommend completing the examples at home before coming into lab. This just entails copy-pasting the examples from Pratt Pundit and trying to understand them. Use the lab time to ask your TA questions about the exercises. Also, check out our summary PowerPoint here for more information.

 

6. Yay!

Finally, I just have to say that I've seen a huge improvement in the quality of lab reports! It's really amazing and I'm really impressed with the reports that have come in so far from grading lab 3. Keep up the good work!

 

Let me know if you have any questions as you wrap up Lab 4 and start working with image processing. So in summary, read the lab documentation, download the image processing toolbox, and most importantly, have fun with the lab!

 

Enjoy the rest of Spring Break!

Sanika

author: Sanika Gupte
title: ECE 280 Lab Blast - Lab 4: Touch Tone Phone
body:
Hi everyone,

 

I hope Exam 1 went well and everyone is staying healthy this week. Four BIG things are addressed in this email, so read it through carefully!

First, I've extended the music competition poll deadline to close this Friday at midnight! It's a really close race and your vote could make a huge impact! You can find the poll on Sakai under the Polls tab.

Second, this week in lab, we will be taking our first leap into communications, specifically with dual-tone multi-frequency (DTMF) encoder/decoder systems. Here's an introduction for the lab, and a general overview can be found here:

1.     What is a Touchtone Phone?

Back in the day, directly following rotary dials (IWF) and required operator assistance, AT&T in 1963 decided to put all the buttons on single touch pad grid, and coin it the "Touchtone Phone". You'd recognize this if you have ever seen a phone with physical buttons on your parent's old flip phone. The buttons on this grid would each activate two sinusoidal tone generators (added via superposition), which would each be tuned to specific frequencies that are all non-harmonic, but well-spaced between 500 and 2000 Hz. These tones would be picked up on the phone microphone and received on the "operator" side. These signals would be interpreted by a machine, not a human operator. This paved the way for many advancements such as more immediate and less demanding operations and even birthed the automated assistant system. In June 15, 2006, the last DTMF system in the US was taken down. Although the system is no longer used for telecommunications, the concepts of correlation and pattern recognition are EVERYWHERE. For example, if you are interested in deep learning and neural networks, similar concepts are deployed to identify features in images.

2.     (CROSS) CORRELATION

Correlation can be used to detect and characterize signals. It is the cousin of convolution and does provide some very useful things to us as signal processors. You can use xcorr(x,y) in MATLAB to implement cross-correlation. The math behind correlation is in the lab documentation and in the slides. Please READ THE LAB DOCUMENTATION before coming in!

Third, Lab 3 is due this week before your corresponding lab section. There is no extension required for this lab report.

Finally, Lab 2 grades will be released shortly, but first, the other TAs and I have compiled some feedback based on the quality of lab reports we have been receiving. Starting with lab 4 reports, we will dock points if we continue to see issues in the professionalism of lab reports. These include first-person usage, misassigned pages, not providing evidence to back up claims, and missing extension sections. I know this all may seem harsh but remember that the TAs are on your side. We want you all to not only build your ability to solve signals problems but also build your ability to clearly and successfully communicate with others.

Like always, feel free to reach out if you have any questions or concerns, and enjoy Lab 4 this week! This is definitely my favorite lab so I hope you all enjoy it.

 

Sanika

author: Sanika Gupte
title: Lab 1 Grades Released and Music Competition
body:
Hi everyone,

 

Lab 1 grades have been released. If you feel like you were graded incorrectly, please submit a regrade request with a SPECIFIC explanation on Gradescope. You all did really well overall, but there are a couple of things that I wanted to address that would set you all up for success in future labs.

1. Extension sections - These sections are mandatory, not optional. They count for the last 7% of your lab grade to go from 93% to 100%. We really want to see independent thought. Just asking questions you found intriguing isn't enough. We want to see you all engaging with figures, data, or creating models and plots. In lab 2 for example, a good extension might be applying the moving average filter you built for exercise 5 to a new data set, like Duke Covid tracker data, and/or experimenting with using more or fewer points in your model (I.e. testing the difference between a 3 point moving average filter and an 8 point moving average filter). In your extension section, you should show plots and also explain what is happening in them/any interesting behavior to get full credit. We are looking forward to seeing what you come up with in future labs!

2. First Person Usage - For these lab reports, we noticed a lot of 1st person tense usage. Please do not use 1st person tense in these reports in the future. We really want you to become better writers from doing these lab reports so please be professional in your writing!

 

As a reminder, please, please, please show up to your lab sections on time. Failure to attend your section on time will result in a 50% penalty on your lab reports.  Please be respectful of your classmate's and TA's time. The TA team hates applying the 50% penalty as much as you all hate receiving it.

 

Finally, we have NO LAB this week to allow you all to prepare for the exam. Good luck and happy studying! Lab 3 will be due the week of 2/28.

 

Now that the administrative stuff is out of the way, *drum roll* it's time for the ECE 280 Music Competition! Vote for your top 3 songs here (on Sakai --> Polls --> Music Competition). Voting closes next Monday at midnight. Everyone did really, really well. Honestly... I would add some of these to my playlist. The TA team is super proud of you all. It was definitely a hard choice to just choose a couple of songs from what was submitted. As a reminder, the winner will get a prize and eternal ECE 280 glory so please vote!

 

Please let us know if you all have any questions, comments, or concerns!

 

Thanks,

Sanika

Everyone should go back and check their submissions for Lab 1 and Lab 2. If you are missed the Duke Community Standard and signature on either report, write the following on a sheet of paper:

"I have adhered to the Duke Community Standard in completing these assignments: ECE 280L Lab 1 and ECE 280L Lab 2."

Then sign the sheet of paper. Send a picture of the paper to your Lab TA, and we will count this as an affirmation of the Duke Community Standard. Please make sure to remember this in the future!

Thanks everyone, and have a great Friday!

author: Chance Fleeting
title: Excessively Long Submissions and Illegibility
body:
Hey Everyone,


I just wanted to share a note. I don't want to throw anyone into a tail-spin with the current assignments, but starting with HW 4, we will no longer accept excessively long submissions. It's unfair for our graders. 

As a general rule, exceeding 3-5 pages of work per question would be deemed excessive. There is some leniency within that count. For instance, with graphical convolution, more space may be required.  However, a submission exceeding 90pgs for 3 problems including pages that contain fewer than 2 complete lines of work is unacceptable.

Additionally, please ensure legibility. We cannot grade what we cannot read, and we will start allowing our graders to reject assignments based on illegibility.

If you are finding it difficult to consolidate your work into a more appropriate length or have concerns regarding legibility, please contact me at chance.fleeting@duke.edu. We can work together to help get things in remedy this situation.

Best,

Chance

author: Chance Fleeting
title: Edit on { Edit on HW3 }
body:
Hey Everyone, 

Actually, after some consideration, jumping into circular convolution in discrete time might be a pretty big leap to throw at you in the middle of this HW... It's important and useful, but kind of derails the DSP train, so I changed Problems 2(a) and 2(e) to each only include 1 periodic signal:

2.a.) y1[n] = (u[n] - u[n-3])*cos(pi n)

2.e.) y2[n] = (u[n] - u[n-3])*(sum of 5 (-1)^k d(n-2k) for all k in the set of integers)

Sorry for the rapid fire versioning, but HW3_v3 is on Sakai and up to date. For those of you who figured out the circular convolution problem, big kudos.

I hope everyone is having a nice day!

Best,

Chance

author: Chance Fleeting
title: Edit on HW3
body:
Hey Everyone,

In an effort to not throw non-convergent summations at you, I've edited P2 (a) and (e):

 

(a) y1[n] = cos(pi n / 2) * cos(pi n)

(e) y5[n] = cos(pi n) * { sum of 5(-1)^k delta(n - 2k) for all k in the set of integers}

 

Hint: both can be simplified with something called circular convolution... do with that what you will.

 

Best of Luck,
Chance

author: Sanika Gupte
title: Lab 3: Digital Audio Effects
body:
Hi everyone,

 

We’ll be back in lab this week for LAB 3: DIGITAL AUDIO EFFECTS. You will be getting more comfortable with using Simulink to implement and listen to some digital audio effects, such as echo, reverb, all-pass reverb, and flanger. These might sound familiar to you if you implemented these in Lab 1 or if you love music! Other fun and relevant terms include: Guitar effects, LFO, bypass, Chorus, Phaser, Early Reflection, Feed Forward, Feedback, Gain, Delay, Acoustic Diffusion.

 

Before attending lab this week you should:

  1. READ THE LAB DOCUMENTATION - it’s always good to do this ahead of time so you have a better understanding of what you’re doing in the limited time you have with your *awesome* TAs
  2. Review a summary of Lab 3 in this powerpoint
  3. Have a set of headphones and/or microphones available for Lab 3
  4. Submit your Lab 2 report on Gradescope - this is due before you come into your lab section

 

***IMPORTANT NOTES***

Please DO THE EXTENSION. This is mandatory, and you will lose unnecessary points for not including this. So please please please take a little time to explore an exercise more in-depth, compare/plot outputs of related signal processing effects, or do additional research on interesting applications of discussed signal processing techniques. Also, when you write your extension, make sure it is included as its own section, so we can easily distinguish what is lab material versus outside exploration. You can ask me or any of the TAs for further clarification about extensions.

Lab attendance is mandatory! We have to apply a 50% penalty if you don't attend a lab section unless you have an excused absence like a STINF or an instructor/dean's excuse. That being said, please communicate with us TAs so we can support you and make sure you have everything you need to be successful.

 

See you all in lab this week,

Sanika

author: Sanika Gupte
title: Lab 2: Intro to Simulink
body:
Hi everyone!

I hope you had some fun this week and made good progress on your songs to make them contest-ready! Y’all are doing an awesome job learning music theory, coding in MATLAB, and exploring cool music effects despite the steep learning curve, and I think y’all are killing it!

This week in lab, we will be exploring the wonderful world of SIMULINK, a graphical programming environment provided by Mathworks, the company behind MATLAB, which is used to make and run models, simulations, and dynamic systems. Effectively, Simulink allows you to "program" using block diagrams, which is really cool and helps you to visualize and comprehend the actual inter-workings of your system. Even though Simulink is completely new for a lot of you, this week’s lab should be relatively straightforward and fast (barring any major technological hiccups). Regardless, it would be helpful to READ THE PROVIDED DOCUMENTATION for Lab 2: Introduction to Simulink, and also mess around with it ahead of time. A brief overview of the lab can be found here.

While lab 2 starts this week, lab 1 will be wrapping up. Before the start of your assigned lab section this week, please:

  • Submit your lab report on Gradescope
    • Append your commented MATLAB code
    • Include a cover page containing a signed (digital signature or NetID) copy of the Duke Community Standard
  • Upload your song .wav file to your Sakai DropBox
  • Lab Reports should be turned in online! Do not turn them in in person. (Let's save some trees!)
  • READ THE LAB 2 DOCUMENTATION & POWERPOINT

If you have any last minute questions about turning in and finishing up Lab 1 please feel free to fire away either here, to your respective TA, or on Ed Discussion. The same goes for any clarification on confusion that you run into when you READ THE PROVIDED DOCUMENTATION and explore Simulink. Additionally, there will be some last-minute office hours for Lab 1 on Monday night (Rishi on Zoom from 8:30-11PM and Clay in Teer 116 from 9-11). Feel free to contact us, and good luck in these final hours of Lab 1: Music Synthesis!

Sanika

author: Woojin Kim
title: Interpretation of HW3 Question 6
body:
Dear students,

I received many questions about Question 6 today, and I certainly saw some possibility that the question could be interpretted in more than one ways (thank you all the students who shared your interpretation!). I will settle it down here.

1) Please assume that you select a ball randomly after choosing a box randomly. (I agree that if you happen to draw a red ball, then your friend certainly knows which box was chosen and thus your friend will certainly win!)

2) How to measure the friend's winning chances? Please assume that your friend will choose a box in a way to maximize the winning chances.  Therefore, if a green ball is drawn, then your friend will compute the probabilty that the green ball comes from Box1 and the probability that it comes from Box2, and then choose the box with a larger probability.

Now you would be able to compute the friend's winning chances, using the rule of average conditional probabilities! Hope this helps!

author: Sanika Gupte
title: Lab 1 Part 2
body:
Hi everyone!

I hope you all have been having fun working on your songs because this week is Lab 1 Part 2! Each of you will be given some building blocks to construct your individual masterpiece. As a reminder, this week you will be expected to apply the techniques discussed last week into generating a specific song, as well as ENHANCEMENTS to make it sound even better, such as Audio Effects, Timbre, Harmonics, Multiple instruments, Instrument Synthesis, Overlapping notes, Dynamic Envelopes, etc.

Now, we won't teach you everything that you can do with these signals to create realistic or enjoyable music. We will be giving you a small subset of things that you can do to make something cool, but this is where it's your turn to shine-- in order to achieve the last 7% of your grade for this lab you will be required to EXPLORE, EXPERIMENT, AND INVESTIGATE deeper and further into this subject to find some more cool stuff, analyze that cool stuff and implement cool stuff. This is called the "extension" which is a mandatory exercise into demonstrating individual thought. Love it or hate it, it is there and very beneficial to the learning process. As said before, while the rest of the report and lab is relatively structured, this is your opportunity to show us what you've got and explore the magical world of signals, systems and signal processing! Your TA will elaborate on this. 

....

Also, a couple of friendly reminders:

1. If you know you absolutely have to miss lab, PLEASE email me, your Lab TA, and Kip to let us know in ADVANCE! Attendance to lab is mandatory and we do take attendance at the start of every class. We want to help you succeed in this lab so let us know and we can try our best to give you the resources you need to succeed.

2. When you're selecting songs, make sure to choose well as this all leads to the famous ECE 280 Music Contest which culminates in everlasting ECE glory as well as a trophy being presented to the top-voted winners. Check out some of the music files from past winners on the Sakai site for inspiration. Take note that you are not allowed to select any music that was originally computer generated as it defeats the purpose of this exercise. 

3. Again, to make everyone's life easier, it is important that you READ THE DOCUMENTS WE HAVE PROVIDED ON SAKAI related to Lab 1 Part 2 before lab. Lab time will be used to work on your song and ask your TA any questions you may have.

Have fun with lab this week! We are looking forward to seeing what you come up with.

 

Sanika

author: Leslie Collins
title: HW1 Problem 1 clarification
body:
Hey all - we received a question about HW1 which states "find the equation for..."  Here is the explanation that Chance and I came up with:

 

We are requesting the closed form equation, for example (freebe alert!), the equation for x1(t) would be x1(t) = 2u(t) + 2u(t-2) - 4u(t-4), so for part (a), we would want 

x1(-2t) = 2u(-2t) + 2u(-2-2t) - 4u(-4-2t) 

= 2u(-t) + 2u(-t-1) - 4u(-t-2) 

= 4u(t+2) -2u(t+1)-2u(t)

and a plot to reflect that compression and reflection.

 

Hope that helps.  Feel free to follow up with email, ask in class tomorrow (in person!), attend TA office hours, or post on Ed.

It was quite exciting to Chance and to me that there was a homework ? on a Wednesday when the homework was posted on Tuesday!

author: Sanika Gupte
title: Lab 1: Music Synthesis
body:
Hello Signal Processors,

 

This week we'll be starting with the first part of the two-part Lab 1: Music Synthesis, in which you will get to synthesize a song of your choice using MATLAB.

  • In the first part of this lab, you will learn how to synthesize simple audio signals in MATLAB using sinusoid waves, vectors, frequency, and duration, read sheet music (notes, rests, key-signatures, tempo, time-signatures), and eventually synthesize a simple song. 
  • Next week in Part 2, you will apply these techniques into generating a specific song, as well as enhancements to make it sound even better, such as Audio Effects, Timbre, Harmonics, Multiple instruments, Instrument Synthesis, Overlapping notes, Dynamic Envelopes, etc. These techniques will be discussed in lab next week.

When you're selecting songs, make sure to choose well as this all leads to the ECE 280 Music Contest, in which top-voted winners are presented with a trophy and glory! *IMPORTANT*: You are not allowed to select any music that was originally computer generated as it defeats the purpose of this exercise. This includes dance music, most of hiphop, and video game music. Please don't do the orchestrated version of the Legend of Zelda or the Undertale soundtrack either (both great games with great music, but too synthesized for you to really learn in this lab).

It is important that you READ THE DOCUMENTS ON SAKAI before lab to make things easier. You can also REFER TO THE POWERPOINT (click here), which outlines important things from the lab document. I'm looking forward to the music you all are going to make!

We will be meeting in person this week in Teer. If you have any questions, comments, or concerns about this lab, don't hesitate to reach out to me, Kip, or your lab TAs.

 

See you all soon,

Sanika
